awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of GatorCloud: Enabling High-Impact Scientific Research and Collaboration via Software Defined Networks and Cloud Services
awd_abstract_narration:
MRI: Acquisition of GatorCloud: Enabling High-Impact Scientific Research and Collaboration via Software-Defined Networks and Cloud Services

Abstract

Cyberinfrastructure has fundamentally transformed the landscape of many disciplines, becoming the engine of change for the next revolution. We propose the GatorCloud cyberinfrastructure to dramatically boost the Campus Research Network (CRN) to over 100Gb/s backbone networks connecting multiple primary sites of data centers across the campus and further enhance it with the cutting-edge software-defined networking (SDN) capabilities and novel cloud services. Additional SDN switches will be deployed across multiple sites of the Florida LambdaRail (FLR).

GatorCloud will strengthen Florida's participation in high-impact national and international projects, such as the CMS experiment that recently discovered the Higgs boson, the Open Science Grid, the Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI), Kepler, and FutureGrid. These projects involve terabyte to petabyte storage and require terascale to petascale computations. With GatorCloud, UF can serve the needs of terabyte data throughput around the world for researchers and their collaborators with transformative capabilities and services. 
	
GatorCloud is the first SDN-enabled campus cloud initiative, offering novel cloud services, such as HPC as a Service (HPCaaS), Network as a Service (NaaS), and Cloud-in-Cloud as a Service (CCaaS). It will have transformative impact on shaping the future of cyberinfrastructure. It provides a production-level environment for research in the forefront of computer science and engineering, e.g., cloud computing and storage, networking, bioinformatics, multimedia, data mining, cyber-physical systems, and parallel and distributed computing. 

It offers a unique interdisciplinary resource for UF and its partners to train and educate graduate and undergraduate students in many related courses and research projects.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we designed and deployed the GatorCloud software-defined networking (SDN) infrastructure, upgrading campus research network (CRN) from 20 Gbps to 200 Gbps at University of Florida (UF). The CRN is designed and managed as a "Science DMZ", leveraging the NSF CC-NIE grant that established the 200G link with the SDN capability from campus to Internet2 via Jacksonville. We further designed and deployed cloud infrastructure: provision a set of cloud services including for big data analytics that can be easily provisioned by researchers on campus. The Golfer SDN controller was designed and developed in the Go language for its efficient and scalable concurrency mechanism. The cloud platform was based on open source frameworks, including OpenStack, Docker, Kubernetes, and SLURM. GatorCloud adopted a hybrid architecture that is elastic with multiple levels of services. covering infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS), container-as-a-service (CaaS), platform-as-a-service (PaaS), and software-as-a-service (SaaS). The SDN networks and cloud services allow domain and application scientists and researchers to boost scientific discoveries in astronomy, physics, chemistry, smart grid, computer vision, transportation, health, and cybersecurity.

Leveraging the GatorCloud infrastructure, we have enriched many courses, such as cloud computing, big data ecosystems, cyber-physical systems, smart grid, pattern recognition, machine learning, and deep learning, computer networks with total enrollment over 1000 graduate/undergraduate students in the duration of the project. We also hosted many undergraduate and graduate students for research and individual study. We hosted groups of K12 students with training lectures and live demonstrations. In addition, campus-wide training sessions on big data, cloud computing, and deep learning were offered. 

Partially supported by this project, our students won Gator Engineering Attribute Award – Creativity Attribute, 2015,  the highest honor in the college of engineering at UF; won three best paper awards in the 15th IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applications (ICMLA 2016), the 13th IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Communication and Networking (SECON 2016), the ACM Cloud and Autonomic Computing Conference (CAC 2013); and won the Internet2 Innovative Application Award in 2013.

Modified by: Xiaolin Li
